math-courses.title: Basic Structures of Mathematics
math-courses.description: Symbolic logic, sets, number systems, relations and operations and topics in probability and statistics.

math-courses.title: Algebra for College Students
math-courses.description: Topics in algebra, graphing and functions. Includes: algebraic and graphical solutions to systems of equations and inequalities; absolute value, polynomial, rational and radical expressions and equations; complex numbers; the function concept; introduction to polynomial, rational and exponential functions and their graphs.
math-courses.prereqs: Math Proficient and appropriate score on Hunter Math Placement Exam

math-courses.title: Mathematics and Everyday Life
math-courses.description: Students will learn how to model real world problems with mathematics, and learn techniques for solving them. Topics include personal finance, statistical reasoning, probability, exponential growth, and voting theory.

math-courses.title: Calculus I
math-courses.description: Limits, continuity, differentiation and integration of elementary functions and trigonometric functions, applications.
math-courses.prereqs: MATH 12550 with a B- or better, or (coreq MATH 14000 and one of MATH 12400, MATH 12500, or MATH 12550), or appropriate score on Hunter Math Placement Exam

math-courses.title: Calculus for Life and Social Sciences
math-courses.description: Limits, continuity and the derivative. The power rule, product and quotient rules, the chain rule, and implicit differentiation. The Mean Value Theorem and the Intermediate Value Theorem. curve sketching and optimization, and linear approximation. Riemann integral and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus. Various applications to economics, life sciences, and physical sciences.
math-courses.prereqs: MATH 12550 with a B- or better, or (coreq MATH 14000 and one of MATH 12400, MATH 12500, or MATH 12550), or appropriate score on Hunter Math Placement Exam

math-courses.title: Calculus II
math-courses.description: Differentiation and integration of transcendental functions, integration techniques, infinite sequences and series, improper integrals, polar coordinates.

math-courses.title: Matrix Algebra
math-courses.description: Systems of linear equations, matrices, determinants, introduction to vector spaces and linear transformations, applications.
math-courses.prereqs: MATH 12400, MATH 12500, MATH 12550, or appropriate score on Hunter Math Placement Exam

stat-courses.title: Elementary Probability and Statistics
stat-courses.description: An introduction to applied statistics and statistical computing. Hands-on data analysis. Graphical inference. The five number summary, box plots, scatterplots, normal probability plots. Elementary probability. Statistical estimation and hypothesis testing. Linear regression. Students are expected to analyze real data sets and write reports.
stat-courses.prereqs: MATH 10100 or appropriate Hunter Math Placement score, and coreq ENGL 12000

stat-courses.title: Discrete Probability
stat-courses.description: Combinations, permutations, discrete probability. Characteristics of probability distributions. Model building. Additional topics like sampling, random walks or game theory will be introduced from time to time.
stat-courses.prereqs: MATH 12400, MATH 12500, MATH 12550, STAT 11300, or appropriate Hunter Math Placement score

stat-courses.title: Introduction to Applied Statistics
stat-courses.description: Sampling, estimation, tests of hypotheses, including one- and two-sample t-tests, two- and three-way tables for nominal and ordinal data, linear regression, analysis of variance through two-way with interaction, appropriate statistical software.
stat-courses.prereqs: MATH 12400, MATH 12500, MATH 12550, or appropriate score on Hunter Math Placement Exam

stat-courses.title: Data Analysis using Statistical Software
stat-courses.description: Familiarity with the Windows computing environment encouraged. Analysis of variance, simple and multiple regression, nonparametric statistics, statistical model building.
stat-courses.prereqs: STAT 21300 or MATH 12400 or MATH 12500 or MATH 12550 and STAT 11300

stat-courses.title: Statistical Analyses in Forensics
stat-courses.description: A second course in probability and statistics and the evaluation of evidence in the forensic sciences.

stat-courses.title: Probability Theory
stat-courses.description: Combinatorics, distribution theory for discrete and continuous random variables, central limit theorems.

stat-courses.title: Stochastic Processes
stat-courses.description: Discrete and continuous stochastic processes including Markov chains, birth processes, queues, and Brownian motion.

stat-courses.title: Introduction to Mathematical Statistics
stat-courses.description: Estimation, hypothesis, testing, confidence limits for normal, binomial, Poisson, and exponential random variables.

stat-courses.title: Bayesian Statistics
stat-courses.description: Fundamental principles and techniques of probability, statistical inference and data analysis, as pertains to the sciences, especially bioinformatics.  Random variables and their distributions.  Central limit theorem.  Conditional probability, Markov chains and Hidden Markov Models. Bayesian statistical paradigm and inference using Markov chain Monte Carlo. Computer simulations and data analysis.
stat-courses.prereqs: MATH 15500, STAT 21200, STAT 21300, STAT 21400, or STAT 31100
